articles.headline: After Iowa, Trump Is Back to Command the National Psyche. He Never Actually Left.
articles.snippet: The former president’s detractors own no earplugs effective enough to block out his steamrolling bid for a third nomination.
articles.abstract: The former president’s detractors own no earplugs effective enough to block out his steamrolling bid for a third nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time, not so long ago, when those wearied and horrified by the presidency of Donald J. Trump could almost convince themselves that the man was gone.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: U.S. Strikes Houthi Targets in Yemen for a Third Time
articles.snippet: The American strikes destroyed four missiles that posed a threat to ships in the Red Sea, the Pentagon said. They came on the third day in a row the Houthis have defiantly fired at passing ships.
articles.abstract: The American strikes destroyed four missiles that posed a threat to ships in the Red Sea, the Pentagon said. They came on the third day in a row the Houthis have defiantly fired at passing ships.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States carried out a new military strike against Houthi ballistic missiles in Yemen on Tuesday, the U.S. military said, but the latest salvo against the Iran-backed group left the White House grappling with how to stop a battle-hardened foe from disrupting shipping lanes critical for global trade.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Saeed Al-Batati

articles.headline: Judge Blocks JetBlue From Acquiring Spirit Airlines
articles.snippet: The ruling is a victory for the Justice Department, which had argued that the merger would reduce competition.
articles.abstract: The ruling is a victory for the Justice Department, which had argued that the merger would reduce competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked JetBlue Airways’ proposed $3.8 billion acquisition of Spirit Airlines, a victory for the Department of Justice, which argued that the deal would harm travelers.
articles.byline: By J. Edward Moreno and Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: China’s Economy Grew Last Year, but Strains Lurk Behind the Numbers
articles.snippet: Gross domestic product expanded 5.2 percent, as China worked to export more to make up for weak demand, high debt and a steep property contraction at home.
articles.abstract: Gross domestic product expanded 5.2 percent, as China worked to export more to make up for weak demand, high debt and a steep property contraction at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Car production set records in China last year. Restaurants and hotels were increasingly full. Construction of new factories surged.

articles.headline: China Told Women to Have Babies, but Its Population Shrank Again
articles.snippet: Faced with falling births, China’s efforts to stabilize a shrinking population and maintain economic growth are failing.
articles.abstract: Faced with falling births, China’s efforts to stabilize a shrinking population and maintain economic growth are failing.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s ruling Communist Party is facing a national emergency. To fix it, the party wants more women to have more babies.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: U.S. to Return Houthis to Terrorism List
articles.snippet: The move is a partial return to a tougher Trump administration stance toward the Iran-backed group, which has attacked commercial ships in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.
articles.abstract: The move is a partial return to a tougher Trump administration stance toward the Iran-backed group, which has attacked commercial ships in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will designate Yemen’s Houthi militia as a terrorist organization, partly reimposing penalties it lifted nearly three years ago on the Iran-backed group whose attacks on regional shipping traffic have drawn a U.S. military response.

articles.headline: Airbus Is Pulling Ahead as Boeing’s Troubles Mount
articles.snippet: With quality control essential, Airbus gains in the rivalry between the world’s biggest plane makers by being seen as “competent.”
articles.abstract: With quality control essential, Airbus gains in the rivalry between the world’s biggest plane makers by being seen as “competent.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Airbus cemented its position last week as the world’s biggest plane maker for the fifth straight year, announcing that it had delivered more aircraft and secured more orders than Boeing in 2023. At the same time, Boeing was trying to put out a huge public-relations and safety crisis caused by a harrowing near disaster involving its 737 Max line of airliners.

articles.headline: A Reporter’s Journey Into How the U.S. Funded the Bomb
articles.snippet: Watching “Oppenheimer,” a journalist wondered (perhaps a bit obsessively): How did the president get the $2 billion secret project past Congress?
articles.abstract: Watching “Oppenheimer,” a journalist wondered (perhaps a bit obsessively): How did the president get the $2 billion secret project past Congress?
articles.lead_paragraph: As I sat in a dark, cavernous movie theater in Berlin watching the film “Oppenheimer,” my mind was thousands of miles away.

articles.headline: Are You a Super Driver? Some States Want to Help You Go Electric.
articles.snippet: A small share of motorists burns about a third of America’s gasoline, a study found. Switching to electric vehicles would make a huge dent in climate-warming emissions.
articles.abstract: A small share of motorists burns about a third of America’s gasoline, a study found. Switching to electric vehicles would make a huge dent in climate-warming emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The key to cutting emissions from cars and light trucks that are heating the planet could lie with the nation’s super drivers, the small percentage of American motorists who drive, on average, about 110 miles per day.

articles.headline: Conservative Justices Appear Skeptical of Agencies’ Regulatory Power
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court considered whether to overrule the seminal 1984 Chevron decision, which requires judges to defer to agencies’ interpretations of ambiguous statutes.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court considered whether to overrule the seminal 1984 Chevron decision, which requires judges to defer to agencies’ interpretations of ambiguous statutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed inclined on Wednesday to limit or even overturn a key precedent that has empowered executive agencies, threatening regulations in countless areas, including the environment, health care and consumer safety.

articles.headline: Electric Car Owners Confront a Harsh Foe: Cold Weather
articles.snippet: In freezing temperatures, the batteries of electric vehicles can be less efficient and have shorter range, a lesson many Tesla drivers in Chicago learned this week.
articles.abstract: In freezing temperatures, the batteries of electric vehicles can be less efficient and have shorter range, a lesson many Tesla drivers in Chicago learned this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Chicago temperatures sinking below zero, electric vehicle charging stations have become scenes of desperation: depleted batteries, confrontational drivers and lines stretching out onto the street.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: Six Reasons Drug Prices Are So High in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Research shows prices in the United States are nearly double those in other well-off countries.
articles.abstract: Research shows prices in the United States are nearly double those in other well-off countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Florida’s plan to save money by importing medications from Canada, authorized this month by the Food and Drug Administration, has renewed attention on the cost of prescription drugs in the United States.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Christina Jewett

articles.headline: Hybrid Cars Enjoy a Renaissance as All-Electric Sales Slow
articles.snippet: Automakers like Ford, Kia and Toyota are offering more hybrid options to appeal to buyers who aren’t ready for fully electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: Automakers like Ford, Kia and Toyota are offering more hybrid options to appeal to buyers who aren’t ready for fully electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Teslas and other electric vehicles dazzled car buyers with futuristic technology and dreams of a gasoline-free future, hybrid cars began to seem like yesterday’s news. Sales of the Toyota Prius, the standard-bearer for hybrids, fell 85 percent over a decade.
